Question: What is the primary purpose of time complexity analysis in algorithms?
Option A: To determine the memory usage of an algorithm
Option B: To analyze the performance of an algorithm
Option C: To compare the speed of different algorithms
Option D: To optimize the coding style of an algorithm
Correct Option: To analyze the performance of an algorithm

Question: Which of the following Notations is used to describe the worst-case time complexity of an algorithm?
Option B: Theta (θ)
Option C: Big O
Option D: All of the above
Correct Option: Big O

Question: If an algorithm has a time complexity of O(n^2), what can be said about its performance as the input size (n) increases?
Option B: The running time will remain constant
Option C: The running time will increase slowly
Option D: The running time will increase rapidly
Correct Option: The running time will increase rapidly
Subtopic Detail: Impact of Input Size on Time Complexity

Question: Which of the following is a characteristic of an algorithm with a space complexity of O(1)?
Option A: It uses a fixed amount of additional memory
Option B: It uses a variable amount of additional memory
Option C: It uses a recursive approach
Option D: It uses dynamic programming
Correct Option: It uses a fixed amount of additional memory

Question: Suppose an algorithm has a recursive function with a time complexity of T(n/2) = 2T(n/4) + O(n). What is the time complexity of this algorithm using the Master Theorem?
Option C: O(n)
Option D: O(log n)
Correct Option: O(n log n)

Question: What is an array in the context of data structures?
Option A: A collection of keys and values.
Option B: A group of variables of the same data type stored together.
Option C: A data structure that allows efficient insertion and deletion.
Option D: A type of algorithm used for sorting data.
Correct Option: A group of variables of the same data type stored together.

Question: What is the primary advantage of using arrays to store data?
Option A: They allow for efficient insertion and deletion of elements.
Option B: They use less memory than linked lists.
Option C: They provide random access to elements.
Option D: They are suitable for large datasets.
Correct Option: They provide random access to elements.

Question: In a linked list, what is the function of a node?
Option A: To store a single element of the list.
Option B: To provide direct access to the entire list.
Option C: To connect multiple lists together.
Option D: To sort the elements of the list.
Correct Option: To store a single element of the list.

Question: How do you insert an element at the beginning of a singly linked list?
Option A: Create a new node and link it to the current head node.
Option B: Traverse the list to find the correct position to insert the node.
Option C: Update the pointers of all existing nodes.
Option D: Shift all elements down by one position to make room for the new node.
Correct Option: Create a new node and link it to the current head node.

Question: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a linked list?
Option B: O(log n)
Option C: O(n)
Correct Option: O(n)
Subtopic Detail: Time Complexity of Linked List Operations

Question: What is the main purpose of a stack data structure?
Option A: To store data in a random manner
Option B: To store data in an ordered manner
Option C: To sort data in ascending order
Option D: To search data in a dataset
Correct Option: To store data in an ordered manner

Question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a queue data structure?
Option B: Last-In-First-Out (LIFO)
Option C: Random Access
Option D: Bidirectional access
Correct Option: First-In-First-Out (FIFO)

Question: What is the time complexity of the enqueue operation in a queue implemented using a linked list?
Option B: O(n)
Option C: O(log n)

Question: Consider a stack implemented using an array. What is the maximum number of elements that can be pushed onto the stack if the array has a size of 5 and it is currently empty?

Suppose we have a queue with 5 elements, and we perform a dequeue operation followed by an enqueue operation. If the queue is implemented using a circular array, what will be the value of the front pointer after these operations?
Option B: It will move one position to the left
Option C: It will move one position to the right
Option D: It will move to the beginning of the array
Correct Option: It will move one position to the right

Question: What is the primary purpose of a hash function in a hash table?
Option A: To sort the data in the table.
Option B: To store the data in the table.
Option C: To compute an index for storing and retrieving data.
Option D: To remove duplicate data from the table.
Correct Option: To compute an index for storing and retrieving data.

Question: What happens when two different keys hash to the same index in a hash table?
Option B: The program crashes.
Option C: A collision occurs and needs to be resolved.
Option D: The data is stored in a separate table.
Correct Option: A collision occurs and needs to be resolved.

Question: Which of the following is a common technique for resolving collisions in a hash table?
Option B: Binary Search
Option C: Bubble Sort
Option D: Merge Sort
Correct Option: Linear Probing

Question: What is the average time complexity of search, insert, and delete operations in a hash table with chaining?
Option B: O(log n)
Option C: O(n)
Subtopic Detail: Time Complexity of Hash Table Operations

Question: Suppose we have a hash table with a load factor of 0.7, and we want to rehash the table to prevent collisions. How many slots should the new table have?
Option A: The same number of slots as the original table
Option B: Twice the number of slots as the original table
Option C: 1/0.7 times the number of slots as the original table
Option D: A prime number of slots greater than the original table
Correct Option: 1/0.7 times the number of slots as the original table

Question: What is the basic idea behind recursive functions?
Option B: To divide the problem into smaller sub-problems
Option C: To use if-else statements for decision making
Option D: To use arrays for storing data
Correct Option: To divide the problem into smaller sub-problems

Question: What happens when a recursive function calls itself?
Option B: The function executes the same block of code again
Option C: A new copy of the function is created on the stack
Option D: The function terminates and goes back to the caller
Correct Option: A new copy of the function is created on the stack

Question: Which of the following is a potential problem with recursive functions?
Option B: They are inefficient and slow
Option C: They can cause a stack overflow if not used carefully
Option D: They are not suitable for parallel programming
Correct Option: They can cause a stack overflow if not used carefully
Subtopic Detail: Recursive Function Calls and Stack Overflow

Question: What is backtracking, in the context of problem-solving?
Option A: A technique to solve problems using iteration
Option B: A method to find the shortest path in a graph
Option C: A technique to explore all possible solutions and revert when a dead end is reached
Option D: A strategy to solve problems using dynamic programming
Correct Option: A technique to explore all possible solutions and revert when a dead end is reached

Question: Which of the following problems is typically solved using backtracking?
Option A: Finding the maximum element in an array
Option B: Solving the traveling salesman problem
Option C: Evaluating a postfix expression
Option D: Finding the nth Fibonacci number
Correct Option: Solving the traveling salesman problem
Subtopic Detail: Examples of Problems Solved using Backtracking
